newsitem.title: USA: Key N.J. unions blast $3 bln bond plan -- paper.
newsitem.headline: Key N.J. unions blast $3 bln bond plan -- paper.

text.p: A coalition of New Jersey unions blasted Gov. Christine Whitman's plan to sell $2.9 billion of pension obligation bonds, but said more concessions might make the unions reconsider their opposition, the Star Ledger reported Wednesday.
The AFL-CIO, a coalition representing several of the state's largest unions, sent lawmakers letters declaring "firm opposition" to the bond plan but left open the possibility of compromise.

The unions said conditions for their support included protecting pension benefits, a reduction in the amount workers contribute to the retirement system, and cancellation of all layoffs planned by the governor.
Whitman said she could not agree to the unions' demands, but remained opened to "reasonable" suggestions, the newspaper said.

The New Jersey Education Association has already come out in favor of the bond plan, which would be used to fully fund the pension system's unfunded liability and free up $647 million of one-shot revenues for the state budget.

The state Assembly is set to vote on the needed legislation next week, but the Senate has not yet scheduled a vote. The Senate Appropriations Committee cancelled hearings Tuesday after Republican leaders decided to try to garner more union support before taking up the measure.
